Graphical abstract The cycloaddtion reaction of CO2 and PO catalyzed by amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids with good balance among various conditions. Numerous ionic liquids have been developed to catalyze the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with epoxides without co-catalyst and organic solvent. Although the catalytic activity is satisfied with cyclic carbonate yield over 90%, the reaction condition is still not regarded as benign enough, especially for reaction temperature and carbon dioxide initial pressure. Four new amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids, AEMPzBr, APMPzBr, AEEPzBr, and APEPzBr, have been firstly synthesized in simple reaction steps with cheap raw materials. Moreover, they would catalyze the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with propyleneoxide under the optimal reaction conditions, 110 °C, 1.5 MPa carbon dioxide initial pressure as well as 1.0 mol% catalyst amount for 4.0 h, with propylene carbonate yield over 94%. The reaction temperature is decreased by 10–20 °C as compared with other single-component ionic liquids. At the same time, the carbon dioxide initial pressure is not increased to keep 1.5 MPa, which is also superior to lots of other ionic liquids, such as imidazolium, pyrazolium, and guanidinium ionic liquids. The recyclability and suitability of amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids are also explored. Finally, the catalytic mechanism is investigated by the density functional theory. Moreover, the influence of weak interactions on the reaction is analyzed by atoms in molecules and non-covalent interactions. As compared with other reported ionic liquids, the reaction condition catalyzed by APEPzBr is more benign with comparable product yield. More importantly, there is good balance among various reaction conditions without sacrificing one to ensure others. Amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids would be a new kind of powerful catalysts for the carbon dioxide fixation. Keywords Amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids Carbon dioxide Epoxide Weak interaction Mechanism 1 Introduction The increased concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in atmosphere have resulted in lots of negative influence on human being [1]. The utilization of CO2 would not only solve the serious environmental problem but also produce many valuable products since CO2 is not limited to greenhouse gas but abundant, non-toxic, and cheap C1 resource [2–4]. The successful transformation of CO2 is also favorable to reducing the employment of hazardous C1 materials including COCl2 and CO [5]. The cycloaddition of CO2 with propyleneoxide (PO) to produce propylene carbonate (PC) is one of the most promising reactions due to the atom efficiency and negative by-product. Many homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [6–9] have been explored, such as, metal oxide [10], modified molecular sieve [11], organometallic complexes [12], and ionic liquids (ILs) [13–16]. Among them, ionic liquids stand out because of the good thermostability, negative vapor pressure, non-flammability, and easy defined structures [17]. More importantly, no additional solvent is required because ionic liquids are excellent solvent for most of organic compounds. The appearance of ionic liquids casts insight on the possibility to develop a single-component catalyst for the fixation of CO2 with high efficiency. In past decades, catalytic activity of ionic liquids has been greatly improved. It is attributed to the most distinguished advantage of ionic liquids, i.e., their properties would be easily tuned by combination of different cation and anion and/or incorporation of functional groups [18,19]. How to refine the reaction condition is still a great challenge for almost all single-component ionic liquids. The 1-methyl-3-o-methylbenzylimidazolium choride ([o-MBzMIM]Cl) presents high catalytic activity with PC yield of 94% under temperature 130 °C and 2.0 MPa CO2 initial pressure with 0.25 mol% catalyst amount during 4.0 h [20]. However, the product yield is sharply deceased when the reaction temperature is decreased by only 10 °C. Certainly, some hydroxyl-functionalized imidazolium ionic liquids have high catalytic activity under 110 °C with PC yield over 92%. However, the required of CO2 initial pressure is still as large as 2.0 MPa [21]. Alternatively, the reaction time is elongated to more than 12.0 h resulting in the lower turnover frequency (TOF) [22]. It is still challenge to explore a single-component catalyst to accelerate the cycloaddition of PO and CO2 in the more mild condition. Recently, a series of pyrazolium ionic liquids have been synthesized by our group [23,24]. Moreover, they present good catalytic activity for the coupling reaction to produce PC, which is comparable or better than the imidazolium ionic liquids [14]. On the basis of them, inclusion of the strong hydrogen bond donor (HBD) is beneficial for activating the PO resulting in the promoted cycloaddition reaction [25,26]. In this work, four amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids (See Fig. 1 ) are firstly synthesized under atmospheric pressure along with 80 °C. Then, they present significant activity for the synthesis of PC with good yield. As compared with other pyrazolium ionic liquids, the reaction temperature is decreased to 110 °C without enhance of CO2 initial pressure and other reaction conditions. The reaction condition reported in this work is more benign along with the competitive production yield than other single-component ionic liquids. The effect of -NH2 group, especially for the contribution of HBD, on the catalytic activity is further elucidated by density functional theory (DFT). Besides the catalytic activity, an good catalyst should also meet other requirements including catalytic conditions, synthesized process, purification of catalyst, and cost. It is better to keep balance among various items rather than outstanding one aspect. 2 Experimental and theoretical details 2.1 Materials and instrument The 1-methypyrazole, 1-ethyl-1H-pyrazole, 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide, 3-bromopropylamine hydrobromide, were purchased from Shanghai DiBo Biochemical Co. Ltd. Oxirane, epichlorohydrin, and styrene oxide were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Propylene oxide and other organic compounds were produced from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., and all of the reagents were used without further purification. The CO2 (99.9%) was obtained from Kaifeng Xinri Gas Co. Ltd. The 1H NMR (400 MHz) and 13C NMR (101 MHz) were run on a Bruker AVANCE III HD spectrometer with TMS as the internal standard. High resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were measured in Agilent 1290 Infinity LC with 6224 TOF MSD. The thermal decomposition temperature was analyzed with a thermal gravimetric analyzer (Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e). GC analyses were performed on an Agilent GC-7890 B using a flame ionization detector. The residue was extracted with a mixed solution of terahydrofuran and methanol and filtered to remove inorganic salt solids. The filtrate was concentrated to give a yellow viscous liquid. 2.2 Preparation of amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids Four amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids were synthesized in two steps including an alkylation reaction and a neutralization reaction. For example, 2-(2-aminoethyl)-1-methyl-pyrazolium bromide was synthesized by the following method. In a three-necked bottle, 1-methylpyrazole (MPz, 2.463 g, 0.03 mol) and 2-bromo-ethylamin hydrobromide (6.12 g, 0.03 mol) were dissolved in 20 mL ethanol. The mixtures were stirred at 80 °C for 72.0 h. After reaction, the mixtures were cooled to room temperature, filtered and washed with ethanol (10 mL × 3). The white powdery solid was obtained after drying in a vacuum oven overnight. The obtained white solid could be directly used in the next reaction without further treatment; then amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids were prepared according to the literature with some revision [25]. The white solid was dissolved in 10 mL H2O and adjusted pH to 9 with KOH solution. The mixture was stirred for 30 min. Then, the water in the system was removed with cyclohexane. Subsequently, the cyclohexane was removed. The obtained mixture was dissolved with methanol-tetrahydrofuran (1:1) and filtered. Next, the solution was concentrated under vacuum. Finally, 2-(2-aminoethyl)-1-methyl-pyrazolium bromide (AEMPzBr) was obtained, which was yellow oily liquid. Then, 2-(3-aminopropyl)-1-methyl-pyrazoliumbromide (APMPzBr), 2-(2-aminoethyl)-1-ethyl-pyrazolium bromide (AEEPzBr), and 2-(3-aminopropyl)-1-ethyl-pyrazolium bromide (APEPzBr) were synthesized with similar procedure to that of AEMPzBr. The structure of amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs were determined by NMR and MS, and the data were provided as follows: AEMPzBr: Yellow oily liquid (yield: 79.85%) 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ: 8.25 (d, J = 7.5, 2.9 Hz, 1H, -N-CH-), 8.18 (d, J = 2.9 Hz, 1H, -N-CH-), 6.77 (t, J = 3.1 Hz, 1H, -CH-), 4.55 (t, J = 6.2 Hz, 2H, H2N-CH2-), 4.14 (s, J = 3.7 Hz, 3H, -N-CH3), 3.15 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H, -N-CH2-). 13C NMR (101 MHz, D2O) δ: 139.67, 138.20, 108.43, 46.62, 37.80, 37.42. m/z: 126.09 [M-Br]+. APMPzBr: Yellow oily liquid (yield: 85.35%) 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ: 8.30 (d, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H, -N-CH-), 8.23 (d, J = 2.9 Hz, 1H, -N-CH-), 6.81 (t, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H, -CH-), 4.56 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H, H2N-CH2-), 4.20 (s, 3H, -N-CH3), 2.79 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, -CH2-), 2.14 (m, J = 7.3, 6.6 Hz, 2H, -N-CH2-). 13C NMR (101 MHz, D2O) δ: 138.15, 136.71, 107.46, 47.88, 37.42, 36.98, 30.65. m/z: 140.12 [M-Br]+. AEEPzBr: Yellow oily liquid (yield: 73.45%) 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ: 8.43 (t, J=2.4 Hz, 2H, -N-CH-), 6.94 (t, J=3.1 Hz, 1H, -CH-), 4.97 (t, J=6.6 Hz, 2H, -N-CH2-), 4.58 (q, J=7.2 Hz, 2H, H2N-CH2-), 3.70 (t, J=6.7 Hz, 2H, -N-CH2-), 1.67 (t, J=7.3 Hz, 3H, -CH2-CH3). 13C NMR (101 MHz, D2O) δ: 138.25, 137.61, 108.66, 46.59, 46.13, 37.97, 13.46. 13.51. m/z: 140.08 [M-Br]+ APEPzBr: Yellow oily liquid (yield: 85.16%) 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ: 8.24 (d, J = 3.0 Hz, 2H, -N-CH-), 6.78 (t, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H, -CH-), 4.48 (m, J = 14.0, 7.2 Hz, 4H, -N-CH2-), 2.70 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H, H2N-CH2-), 2.06 (m, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H, -CH2-), 1.56 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H, -CH3). 13C NMR (101 MHz, D2O) δ: 136.84, 136.20, 107.67, 47.89, 45.58, 37.49, 31.00, 13.57. m/z: 154.04 [M-Br]+. 2.3 Cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides The cycloaddition reaction was performed in the high pressure reactor (100 mL). In a typical run, the epoxide/catalyst mixture were added to the reaction kettle in a certain proportion. Then CO2 was filled into the high pressure cell with the desired pressure. The reaction was stirred at designed temperature for 1.0–5.0 h. After the reaction was completed, the kettle was cooled to room temperature in an ice-water bath. Then, the remaining CO2 was slowly released to the atmosphere. The final products were obtained by distillation under reduced pressure for the liquid products or by column chromatography for the solid products. The product selectivity was detected by GC analysis. 2.4 Theoretical details The equilibrium geometries of all the stationary points, including reactants, intermediates, and transition states, were optimized by Becke’s three parameter exact exchange functional combined with the Perdew and Wang (B3PW91) [27,28] function with the 6–31 G(d,p) basis set [29]. At the same level, the vibrational frequencies were calculated to characterize the nature of stationary point and to make the zero-point energy (ZPE) correction. The minimum-energy path (MEP) was constructed on the basis of the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) method to verify that the transition state is connected with two desired minima [30]. On the basis of the optimized geometries, the energy was refined at the M06/6-311+G(2d,2p) level [31] in Et2O solvent by the polarized continuum model (PCM) [32,33]. All aforementioned calculations involved in this work were completed by the Gaussian 09 program package [34]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthetic and property of amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs The synthetic route of the amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids is shown in Scheme 1 . The target ionic liquids could be synthesized by two simple steps including alkylation reaction and neutralization reaction. The yield of alkylation reaction is over 85%. While the other step is only neutralization reaction performed under room temperature. Then, the water in ionic liquids is removed by cyclohexane. The products are characterized by NMR and MS (ESI) to confirm that the desired ionic liquids have been synthesized. There are some highlighted advantages for amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids. The raw materials are pyrazoles and halogenated hydrocarbons, which are abundant and inexpensive. The reaction condition is easy to reach (80 °C and atmospheric pressure) along with relative high product yield and simple post-treatment. If amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs would show high catalytic activity for the coupling reaction of CO2 with PO, they would be promising candidates for further scale up application. 3.2 Effect of catalysts The catalytic activity of four synthesized amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids is investigated via the model reaction of PO with CO2 in the absence of solvent and co-catalyst (See Scheme 2 ). The results are summarized in Table 1 . When the alkyl group substituted on N1 atom is fixed, the catalytic activity is enhanced with the increase of alkyl chain length substituted on N2 atom with the following sequence: APMPzBr (92%) > AEMPzBr (89%) and APEPzBr (94%) > AEEPzBr (76%). If the substituted alkyl group connected with -NH2 group is fixed, the ethyl group is more suitable to be the other substituted group rather than methyl group. As a result, APEPzBr has the best catalytic activity with the PC yield of 94%. All reactions listed in Table 1 are performed under the following reaction conditions: PO 100 mmol, temperature 110 °C, 1.5 MPa CO2 initial pressure, catalyst amount 1.0 mol%, and reaction time 4.0 h. The catalytic activity for 2-bromo-ethylamin hydrobromide and 2-bromo-ethylamin hydrobromide/MPz (entry 5 and entry 6), which are the raw materials to synthesize the amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids, is also investigated by us. The combination of 2-bromo-ethylamin hydrobromide and MPz present some extent catalytic activity for the title reaction. However, 2-bromo-ethylamin hydrobromide almost has no catalytic activity for the reaction of CO2 and PO. It is necessary to synthesize the ionic liquids to get the high catalytic activity. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of APEPzBr is compared with other imidazolium, pyrazolium, and guanidinium ILs with or without -NH2 functionalized group. As compared with APEPzBr (See Table S1 in the supporting information), the catalytic activity of DEPzBr is comparable with almost the same PC yield [23]. However, reaction temperature required for coupling reaction with APEPzBr as catalyst is decreased by 10 °C. Moreover, the required CO2 initial pressure is lower for APEPzBr. Additionally, APEPzBr presents the higher catalytic activity than BMImBr [21]. The reaction time for the latter is much shorter than that for APEPzBr. However, the PC yield is slightly improved even if the reaction time is further elongated. The CO2 initial pressure is decreased to 1.5 MPa in the presence of [HIm]Br, but the reaction temperature still keeps 120 °C [35]. According to the literature, the catalytic performance of other traditional ILs, such as quaternary ammonium salts [36], phosphonium salts [37], and pyridinium salts [38], is even less than that of BMImBr. Therefore, they are not compared anymore. Inclusion of -NH2 group greatly promotes the catalytic performance, especially for the combination with pyrazole cation. As compared with [APbim]I [25] and [TMGC2H4NH2]Br [39], the PC yield catalyzed by APEPzBr is comparable with more mild reaction conditions, especially for temperature. The reaction temperature with [TMGC2H4NH2]Br as catalyst is 20 °C larger than that with APEPzBr as catalyst. The anion in [APbim]I is I−, which has the better nucleophilic activity than Br− anion indicating the better catalytic activity in combination of the same cation. However, the reaction temperature with [APbim]I as catalyst is still as high as 120 °C. Up to date, the HEMIMB stands out from various homogeneous catalysts with PC yield of 99.2%. However, not only the reaction temperature (125 °C) is very high but also the employed catalyst amount (1.6 mol%) is much larger than other ionic liquids [36]. Combination of various items, the performance of HEMIMBr is not better than that of APEPzBr. 3.3 Effect of reaction parameters APEPzBr is employed as an example to explore the optimal reaction condition including catalyst amount, reaction temperature, CO2 initial pressure, and reaction time. Before optimization, it is better to confirm the thermostability of amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids. The thermogravimetic analysis (TGA) of APEPzBr is presented in Fig. 2 APEPzBr is stable below 200 °C suggesting that it would not dissolve in the cycloaddition reaction. First, the effect of catalyst amount on PC yield is carried out, and the corresponding result is shown in Fig. 3 . The yields of PC enhance from 57% to 94% when the amount of catalyst dosage increases from 0.2 mol% to 1.0 mol%. When the catalyst dosage is increased from 0.3 mol% to 0.5 mol%, the enhanced extent of PC yield is much larger in this region. After 1.0 mol% of catalyst dosage, the yield of PC is almost kept even if the amount of catalyst dosage is further increased. Therefore, the 1.0 mol% of catalyst dosage is a turning point. Next, the influence of reaction temperature is determined (See Fig. 4 ). The PC yield improves sharply from 55% to 94% when the reaction temperature increases from 80 °C to 110 °C. After that, the PC yield is kept or have a slight decrease with the further increase of temperature, which is similar with the variation of catalyst dosage. However, the varied extent is not totally the same. The increased extent of PC yield is almost the same for every 10 °C enhancement of reaction temperature. Different from catalyst dosage, there is not acutely enhancement in a specified temperature range. The viscosity of APEPzBr would be decreased with the increase of temperature, which is favorable for the CO2 absorption. Consequently, the coupling reaction of CO2 with PO would also be promoted. However, the CO2 captured by amino-based ILs would be released at high temperature, which is unfavorable for enhancing the concentration of CO2 [40]. As a result, the product yield has a slight decrease after 110 °C. After that, the influence of CO2 initial pressure is explored. As shown in Fig. 5 , the 1.5 MPa is the balance point between PC yield and CO2 initial pressure. The PC yield would be increased by 22% when the CO2 initial pressure enhances from 0.5 MPa to 1.5 MPa. It is difficult to decrease the CO2 initial pressure with an good PC yield. Normally, the 2.0 MPa CO2 initial pressure is reported in literature for single-component ionic liquid. It is highlighted that the CO2 initial pressure would be decreased by 0.5 MPa with APEPzBr as catalyst. Finally, the influence of reaction time is discussed (See Fig. 6 ). In the first four hours, the yield of PC increases rapidly up to 94%. Then, the variation of PC yield is negligible. Only the elongation of reaction time would not increase the PC yield. When the catalyst is fixed, the PC yield is mainly determined by other aspects rather than the reaction time. In general, the optimal reaction conditions are PO 100 mmol, temperature 110 °C, 1.5 MPa CO2 initial pressure, catalyst amount 1.0 mol%, and reaction time 4.0 h. The selectivity of PC is almost not affected by the variation of reaction parameters with the value over 99%. As compared with other single-component ionic liquids, reaction temperature and CO2 initial pressure are two prominent advantages for amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs. More importantly, aforementioned items would be achieved in the same reaction, which provide insight into the development of high efficient catalyst by combination of different cation and anion. 3.4 Recyclability of the catalyst Reusability is also an important criterion to evaluate performance for catalyst, especially for the homogeneous catalyst. The coupling reaction of CO2 and PO is performed under the aforementioned optimal reaction conditions with APEPzBr as catalyst. After that, the mixture is distilled under 0.01 MPa and 140 °C to remove a large amount of propylene carbonate. The residue is washed with ethyl acetate by three times (30 ml × 3). After the ethyl acetate is removed, the APEPzBr dried under vacuum. Then, the regenerated APEPzBr is utilized to catalyze the coupling reaction again. As shown in Fig. 7 , the catalytic activity of APEPzBr is not decreased after it is utilized by 5 times with the PC yield around 94%. The reusability of APEPzBr is medium as compared with other single-component ILs, such as, [o-MBzMIM]Cl [20], DEPzBr [23], and HEPzI [24]. 3.5 Catalytic activity on other epoxides A promising catalyst not only has the good catalytic activity but also has the extensive suitability. The performance of APEPzBr to catalyze other epoxides is investigated under the optimum reaction conditions. The corresponding results are summarized in Table 2 . The selectivity of cyclic carbonate is over 99% for all investigated substrates. The product yield of 1,3-dioxolan-2-one (entry 1) is the highest because of the less steric hindrance of ethylene oxide. Moreover, the anion has the same possibility to activate two C atoms in ethylene oxide leading to more active nucleophilic activation. The product yield of 4-(chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (entry 3) is the lower than that of PC (entry 2), which is similar with most of ionic liquids including carboxyl group and hydroxy group [26,36,41]. They would have strong interaction with the Cl atom in epichlorohydrin by hydrogen bonding. Correspondingly, they have the less possibility to activate the O atom of PO leading to the less product yield. To testify aforementioned statement, the binding energy between APEPzBr and epichlorohydrin is calculated at the M06/6-311+G(2d,2p)(PCM)//B3PW91/6–31 G(d,p) level in Et2O. Since the APEPzBr would transfer to the 2-(3-(carboxyamino)propyl)-1-ethyl-pyrazolium bromide (CAPEPzBr), the latter is the real catalytic component. The binding energy between CAPEPzBr and Cl atom in 4-(chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one is 4.71 kcal/mol, which is the larger than that between CAPEPzBr and O atom (1.97 kcal/mol). Therefore, the electrophilic activation to promote the ring-opening of reactant is weaken. When ionic liquids with other functional groups are employed as catalyst, the product yield of 4-(chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one would be larger than that of PC because no strong hydrogen bond is formed between ionic liquid and reactant [42,43]. Except for 3-phenoxy-1,2-epoxypropane (entry 6), other product yields are comparable over 89% suggesting the good suitability of APEPzBr. When the coupling reaction of CO2 with 3-phenoxy-1,2-epoxypropane is catalyzed by APEPzBr, the yield of 4-(phenoxymethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one is only 66% with the higher reaction temperature of 140 °C and 2.0 MPa CO2 initial pressure. As compared with other ILs, the catalytic activity of APEPzBr is much better, which is also suitable for most of epoxides rather than only PO. 3.6 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism of coupling reaction of CO2 with PO catalyzed by various ILs has been extensively investigated in previous literature [44,45]. However, the reaction mechanism catalyzed by amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs is more complicated since there are two catalytic components in catalytic system. It has been testified that the amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs would react with CO2 leading to carboxyamino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs [46]. After that, both amino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs and carboxyamino-functionalized pyrazolium ILs would catalyze the coupling reaction. Since there are two components, the “Single-IL” model is not suitable to study it. “Double-IL” model is applied to study the possible reaction routes with AEEPzBr as catalyst. 52 reaction routes are designed on the basis of different electrophilic activation along with different catalytic components (See Table S2). Only the ring-opening step is considered since it is the rate-determining step even if in the “Double-IL” model [47]. The possible reaction routes are classified into three types: one is that both components are employed as electrophile including two AEEPzBr, two CAEEPzBr (1-(2-(carboxyamino)ethyl)-2-ethyl-1H-pyrazol-2-ium bromide), and AEEPzBr along with CAEEPzBr; the second situation is that one component is responsible for electrophilic activation and the other component is responsible for stabilizing the former one; the last situation is that two catalytic components form a circle with the PO. When one catalytic component is fixed, the other catalytic component would be turned over leading to the different comformations because of the asymmetric substituted group of catalyst. Unfortunately, some transition states are not located. As a result, 47 routes are successfully confirmed. The most favorable route is that one CAEEPzBr is employed as the electrophile to activate the PO and the other CAEEPzBr is employed to stabilize the former one by hydrogen bonds. Following the same activation mode, the reaction routes for other three catalysts are located. As shown in Fig. 8 , the calculated barrier heights are decreased in the order of TS3-2 (AEEPzBr, 13.30 kcal/mol) > TS1-2 (AEMPzBr, 13.02 kcal/mol) > TS2-2 (APMPzBr, 12.86 kcal/mol) > TS4-2 (APEPzBr, 12.66 kcal/mol), which is consistent with the measured catalytic activity in experiment. To further testify the formation of CAEEPzBr, the FT-IR spectra of APEPzBr and recovered catalyst after the reaction are presented in Fig. 9 . In Fig. 9a, the characteristic absorbance at 1604 cm−1 is assigned to the vibration of -NH2 group. For the recovered catalyst, there is the other absorbance at 1685 cm−1 near to the vibration of -NH2 group, which is ascribed to the vibration of the carbonyl group in carbamic acid. The appearance of carbamic acid group is also testified the rightness of proposed mechanism. 3.7 AIM and NCI analysis The ring-opening of PO is activated by both electrostatic and hydrogen bond interaction, which has been testified in previous literature [48]. Besides the electrostatic interaction, other weak interactions have contribution for the ring-opening of PO. The contribution of weak interactions played in ring-opening step is analyzed by non-covalent interaction (NCI) [49,50] and atoms in molecule (AIM) [51,52] method to deeply understand them. Only some important interactions related with electrophilic and nucleophilic attack in the catalytic central region are listed in Table 3 . The corresponding 3D plots are shown in Fig. 10 . The Br1…C1 is non-covalent interaction with the positive ∇2 ρ value. In contrast, the O2-H1…O1 is covalent interactions with the negative ∇2 ρ value indicating that the H1 atom has transferred from cation to PO in the transition state. Although the Br1…C1 interaction in TS4-2 is not stronger than that in TS2-2, the barrier height of the former is the lower. It is mainly attributed to the strongest O2-H1…O1 interaction in TS4-2. As a result, the electrophilic attack plays the more important role in TS4-2. In contrast, the lower barrier height of TS2-2 is mainly resulted by the stronger Br1…C1 interaction with the Sign(λ2)ρ value of -0.03352. It is interesting that both the Br1…C1 interaction and O2-H1…O1 interaction in TS3-2 are the stronger than those in TS1–2, which is not consistent with their barrier heights. However, the C2-H2…Br1 and C3-H3…Br1 interactions in TS1-2 are much larger than those in TS3-2 suggesting the critical role of hydrogen bonds to stabilize the whole catalytic system. Overall, the contribution of both nucleophilic and electrophilic activation is important to promote the ring-opening of PO, which is difficult to differentiate them. 4 Conclusion Four amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids, AEMPzBr, APMPzBr, AEEPzBr, and APEPzBr, have been firstly synthesized. Their synthetic routes are simple associated with benign reaction conditions and easy purification. They present good catalytic activity for the coupling reaction of CO2 with PO, especially for APEPzBr, with PC yield of 94%. The optimal reaction conditions are 110 °C, 1.5 MPa CO2 pressure with 1.0 mol% catalyst amount for 4.0 h, which is more benign than most of reported single-component ionic liquids. The reaction temperature is greatly decreased by 10 °C. At the same time, the CO2 initial pressure is not increased to keep 1.5 MPa, which is superior to other ionic liquids. APEPzBr would be utilized by five times without obvious decrease for catalytic activity. Moreover, it presents good suitability for lots of common epoxides. The catalytic mechanism is elucidated by “Double-IL” model suggesting that one APEPzBr activates the PO and the other APEPzBr stabilizes the whole catalytic system. coredata.dc:description: Numerous ionic liquids have been developed to catalyze the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with epoxides without co-catalyst and organic solvent. Although the catalytic activity is satisfied with cyclic carbonate yield over 90%, the reaction condition is still not regarded as benign enough, especially for reaction temperature and carbon dioxide initial pressure. Four new amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids, AEMPzBr, APMPzBr, AEEPzBr, and APEPzBr, have been firstly synthesized in simple reaction steps with cheap raw materials. Moreover, they would catalyze the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with propyleneoxide under the optimal reaction conditions, 110 °C, 1.5 MPa carbon dioxide initial pressure as well as 1.0 mol% catalyst amount for 4.0 h, with propylene carbonate yield over 94%. The reaction temperature is decreased by 10–20 °C as compared with other single-component ionic liquids. At the same time, the carbon dioxide initial pressure is not increased to keep 1.5 MPa, which is also superior to lots of other ionic liquids, such as imidazolium, pyrazolium, and guanidinium ionic liquids. The recyclability and suitability of amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids are also explored. Finally, the catalytic mechanism is investigated by the density functional theory. Moreover, the influence of weak interactions on the reaction is analyzed by atoms in molecules and non-covalent interactions. As compared with other reported ionic liquids, the reaction condition catalyzed by APEPzBr is more benign with comparable product yield. More importantly, there is good balance among various reaction conditions without sacrificing one to ensure others. Amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids would be a new kind of powerful catalysts for the carbon dioxide fixation.
coredata.dc:title: Combination of experimental and theoretical methods to explore the amino-functionalized pyrazolium ionic liquids: An efficient single-component catalyst for chemical fixation of CO2 under mild conditions
